- Make reading/being made aware of the JEID committee part of onboarding (e.g. a process for new employees to disclose information they want to) or pointing new employees to important resources around how to discuss JEID 
- I'd love to see more resources about disability, e.g. language + how to talk about disability,  hidden/invisible/dynamic disabilities, making content accessible etc.

jeid_previous_experiences_open:
Yes - I have a fair amount of negative experience related to this type of initiatives. In my previous work experience, we were "forced" to participate in a diversity training, which was one of the worst experiences I have ever had. We were forced to share personal information and talk about our feelings in an unsafe environment (there was no enough trust in the organization between people, so how can one share anything personal?), and the format resembled a psychotherapy session, which to me was unacceptable. In addition to that, the content was not tailored for our reality / needs / context and therefore, didn't bring any value. 

I also think that there have been many instances worldwide in which these JEID-type of initiatives have been implemented under false pretenses (for the wrong reasons), or implemented because "they had to be implemented to show that we are doing something". I think that such an approach can cause more harm than help, as it can create a lot of negative feelings in participants / recipients of such initiatives. Being mindful of that and keeping people's skepticism in mind might be helpful, as it may show folks that all voices are heard.

As part of the hiring process (for a high-level position), all candidates were required to write a statement on their commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion and talk about past examples of how they implement it. I am unsure of how ineffective this is, as I see this more of a self-promotion piece than clear examples of a candidate's track record in DEI. This might be something to avoid for interviews, but it is also useful for digging into a candidate's experience with JEID.
rp_additional_feedback_open:
My opinions regarding DEI is as follows:

First, DEI felt like something that appeared into the limelight out of nowhere with the past ten years due to business adopting it, but it shouldn't be treated as such. One of the constant struggles I believe DEI/JEID faces in its reputation is that it feels as if it is something being implemented top-down, even if many people largely agree with the need for it. The difficult part is ensuring that JEID is not just communicated top-down, but it feels as if it is being brought from bottom-up, in a genuine, bona fide manner. Thus, as the JEID committee develops its bylaws, goals, and policies, I believe that it is important to remember this.

Second, part of JEID I believe is not discussed as prominently is power. We believe that power is sanctioned and controlled from a central figure (like a ruler), but according to Michel Foucault, power is actualized, exercised, and experienced in the perimeters and extremities of the system, and we should see power as something that everyone has in varying, unequal degrees (Foucault, "Power, Right, Truth"). This means that the insight and analysis of power is most important when we look at how, for example, a white working-class person discriminates against a black person, instead of looking at how the US Congress' explicit discriminatory policies subjugates disadvantaged peoples. In other words, discriminatory policies and discrimination in general are not the result of a single person/subjugator/ruler, but the product of a system that subjugates us and that we simultaneously contribute to. So, in creating policies and more generally, culture-building, everyone should feel included in contributing to the organization and feel empowered to exercise their power in an equitable, non-zero-sum game manner while recognizing the stratified nature of power in our society.

In the end, there aren't any solid suggestions that I'm communicating here, but I hope that my opinion can reveal more insight and things to keep in mind as JEID develops its goals.

While I'd like to hope that people at RP will feel comfortable coming forward if they feel like they are experiencing/seeing discrimination/harassment, but the reality is there may be things going on that we're entirely unaware of. I think if the JEID committee was able to somehow capture/anticipate what may be happening without anyone necessarily realizing it, that would be beneficial. For example, bias towards possible candidates, creating events or an environment that make people feel excluded so they don't come, etc. Oftentimes discrimination or exclusion can happen without awareness, and that's often the most underreported/acknowledged. 

I also think offering diversity/cultural training would be beneficial!

I think RP is currently very successful at DEI. I think the committee would do well to solidify those successes and make sure that those values are institutionalized as the organization grows. 

I also think that cause diversity and cause neutrality go hand-in-hand with DEI, and I would like if the JEID committee perhaps tried to pin down that disposition and style communication of respecting different worldviews/backgrounds/priors that makes RP work as a multi-cause EA org and as an employer of diverse people.

jeid_previous_experiences_open:
I've really disliked a lot of the DEI orgs at my previous jobs. In those cases, they seemed either uninterested in communicating with anyone who had a different opinion (even if they agreed that the issue at hand was real and a problem) or they created a lot of bloat with little apparent benefit. Diversity, equity, and inclusion are not the sole province of social justice, but I've never seen a DEI committee that wasn't dominated by social justice/woke ideas, which is alienating to me because I have intellectual disagreements with that philosophy.

I can't imagine anyone I know at RP failing that seriously, but bloat seems like a live possibility.

rp_additional_feedback_open:
I think the parental leave policy is really generous, and I appreciate that it applies to both pregnancy and adoption (and I imagine there would be some provision for fostering, if needed?) However, it does seem like it doesn't adequately take into account how work is likely to be affected for anyone bearing a child, vs other parents. I think the two things that strike me the most are the following. 1) Our policy says that "leave can be taken as desired within the first two years of a new child’s life", which suggests that the leave cannot begin before the child is born/ adopted? It might be beneficial for parents to begin a few weeks beforehand. 2) According to the policy, "pay and hours for the parental leave will be the average of the pay you received over the two month prior notice period". If a child bearing parent needs to reduce hours in the late stages of pregnancy - because they simply cannot keep up with a full time job - then it seems that this will impact their earning potential for the period of their leave. In contrast, a non-child-bearing parent would probably be able to continue to work full hours and therefore receive higher pay.

I've been impressed by the commitment to ensuring that those with dependents can attend the team retreat without bearing additional costs.
